references: and SOTA FL methods on both Federated image and text classification problems with large scale convolutional and transformer models respectively. For our image classification problems we train ResNet-
type models on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 and use STL-10, CIFAR-100 and SVHN as well as different subsets of ImageNet (Mammals, Birds, Dogs, Devices, Invertebrates, Structures)
The methodology for generating these subsets is described in Appendix
as auxiliary data. In our experiments, we always use 80% of the auxiliary data as distillation data
. For our text classification problems we train Tiny-Bert
Federated Learning environment and Data Partitioning
: We consider Federated Learning problems with up to
participating clients. In all experiments, we split the training data evenly among the clients according to a dirichlet distribution following the procedure outlined in
. This allows us to smoothly adapt the level of non-iid-ness in the client data using the dirichlet parameter
varying between 100.0 and 0.01. A value of
results in an almost identical label distribution, while setting
results in a split, where the vast majority of data on every client stems from one single class. See Appendix
for a more detailed description of our data splitting procedure. We vary the client participation rate
For our image classification problems, we use contrastive representation learning as described in
for pre-training. We use the default set of data augmentations proposed in the paper and train with the Adam optimizer, learning rate set to
and a batch-size of 512. For our text classification problems, we pre-train using self-supervised next-word prediction.
Training the Scoring model and Privacy Setting:
We set the default privacy parameters to
. To clearly discern the performance benefits of the two components of
(unsupervised pre-training and weighted ensemble distillation), we also report performance metrics on versions of these methods where the auxiliary data was used to pre-train the feature extractor
we set the sample size to 10 as suggested in the paper. For
we always tune the proximal parameter
On all image classification task, we use the very popular Adam optimizer
, with a fixed learning rate of
and a batch-size of 32 for local training. Distillation is performed for one epoch for all methods using Adam at a batch-size of 128 and fixed learning rate of
. More detailed hyperparameter analysis in Appendix
shows that this choice of optimization parameters is approximately optimal for all of the methods. If not stated otherwise, the number of local epochs

references: Table 5 compares performance of FedAUX to baseline methods on the CIFAR-100 data set. Again FedAUX outperforms FedAVG and FedDF across all level of data heterogeneity α𝛼\alpha and shows superior performance to the improved FedDF+P when data is highly heterogeneous at α={0.01,0.04}𝛼0.010.04\alpha=\{0.01,0.04\}. Interestingly in this setting FedDF+P manages to slightly outperform FedAUX at medium data heterogeneity levels α={0.16,0.64}𝛼0.160.64\alpha=\{0.16,0.64\}. This indicates that our proposed differentially private certainty scoring method may insufficiently approximate the true client certainty in this setting. We leave potential improvements of this mechanism for future work.

references: To simulate the effects of a wide variety of auxiliary data sets on the training performance of FedAUX, we generate different structured subsets of the ImageNet data base (resized to 32×32×33232332\times 32\times 3). Each subset is defined via a top-level Wordnet ID which is shown in Table 6. To obtain the images from the subset, we select all leaf-node IDs of the respective top-level IDs via the Imagenet API
and then take only those classes from the full Imagenet data set, which match these leaf-node IDs. Table 6 also shows the number of samples contained in every subset that was generated this way.

references: As mentioned in section 4.3 Evaluating FedAUX on NLP Benchmarks we used TinyBERT as a model for our NLP experiments. TinyBERT was pre-trained on Bookcorpus444https://huggingface.co/datasets/bookcorpus which led us to select the same dataset as a public dataset in order to follow the methodology outlined in section 3.3. As private datasets we chose the AG News dataset555https://huggingface.co/datasets/ag_news (Zhang et al., 2015), a topic classification dataset, and the english texts from the Multilingual Amazon Reviews Corpus666https://huggingface.co/datasets/amazon_reviews_multi (Keung et al., 2020), which we use for predicting how many stars a review gets. The pre-trained weights and the tokenizer for TinyBERT are available at the corresponding repository777https://huggingface.co/huawei-noah/TinyBERT_General_4L_312D. All experiments were conducted using ϵ=0.1italic-ϵ0.1\epsilon=0.1 and δ=10−5𝛿superscript105\delta=10^{-5} as differential privacy parameters, 1 epoch for local training and distillation, ten clients and 100% participation rate as well as 160000 disjoint data points, which were sampled from BookCorpus, for the public and distillation datasets respectively. Furthermore the ADAM optimizer with a learning rate of 10−5superscript10510^{-5} was used for both local training and distillation. The regularization strength of the logistic regression classifier was set to 0.010.010.01. The batch size for Di,D−subscript𝐷𝑖superscript𝐷D_{i},D^{-} and Dd​i​s​t​i​l​lsubscript𝐷𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑡𝑖𝑙𝑙D_{distill} was 32. Detailed results for figure 5 are depicted in table 7.
